A Data Fusion Model for Meteorological Data using the INLA-SPDE method

Stephen Jun Villejo \ORCID0000-0002-0510-3143 â€ƒâ€ƒ Sara Martino â€ƒâ€ƒ Finn Lindgren â€ƒâ€ƒ Janine B Illian \orgdivSchool of Mathematics and Statistics, \orgnameUniversity of Glasgow, \orgaddress\stateGlasgow, \countryUnited Kingdom \orgdivDepartment of Mathematical Sciences, \orgnameNorwegian University of Science and Technology, \orgaddress\stateTrondheim, \countryNorway \orgdivSchool of Mathematics, College of Science and Engineering, \orgnameUniversity of Edinburgh, \orgaddress\stateEdinburgh, \countryUnited Kingdom \orgdivSchool of Statistics, \orgnameUniversity of the Philippines Diliman, \orgaddress\stateQuezon City, \countryPhilippines
(2023; 2023; Date; Date; Date)
Abstract

This work aims to combine two primary meteorological data sources in the Philippines: data from a sparse network of weather stations and outcomes of a numerical weather prediction model. To this end, we propose a data fusion model which is primarily motivated by the problem of sparsity in the observational data and the use of a numerical prediction model as an additional data source in order to obtain better predictions for the variables of interest. The proposed data fusion model assumes that the different data sources are error-prone realizations of a common latent process. The outcomes from the weather stations follow the classical error model while the outcomes of the numerical weather prediction model involves a constant multiplicative bias parameter and an additive bias which is spatially-structured and time-varying. We use a Bayesian model averaging approach with the integrated nested Laplace approximation (INLA) for doing inference. The proposed data fusion model outperforms the stations-only model and the regression calibration approach, when assessed using leave-group-out cross-validation (LGOCV). We assess the benefits of data fusion and evaluate the accuracy of predictions and parameter estimation through a simulation study. The results show that the proposed data fusion model generally gives better predictions compared to the stations-only approach especially with sparse observational data.

keywords:
data fusion, integrated nested Laplace approximation (INLA), Bayesian model averaging

1 Introduction

A common aim in spatial statistical modelling is to predict values of a spatial variable at unsampled locations, based on measurements taken at a finite â€“ and often relatively small â€“ number of locations. In the context of environmental sciences and meteorology in particular, data on e.g.Â air-quality, environmental pollution, surface temperature, or rainfall are collected through a network of monitoring stations (lawson2016handbook, ; lee2017rigorous, ; blangiardo2016two, ; greven2011approach, ; chien2014impact, ; arab2014modelling, ; jaya2022spatiotemporal, ; lee2015impact, ). These data are used for prediction, and for understanding the spatio-temporal dynamics of the underlying processes and the impact of these variables on potential outcomes of interest, such as health outcomes. However, due to the high maintenance costs, the monitoring networks are typically spatially sparse lawson2016handbook . Increasingly, data from additional sources derived from satellite images or outcomes of numerical models with a high spatial resolution are available. These can be used jointly with the monitoring data to improve the accuracy of predictions in a process that combines information from different data sources and is often referred to as data fusion or data assimilation (bauer2015quiet, ; gettelman2022future, ; lawson2016handbook, ). The goal is to exploit the better spatial resolution of the additional data to fill gaps in areas only sparsely covered by the monitoring stations in order to predict and map the variables into space with more accuracy at smaller scales than based on the monitoring stations data alone. However, a general issue that is common in attempts to combine data from more than one source is that the various data streams differ in their quality. Numerical or satellite data, specifically, are often biased due to calibration issues, and these biases have to be accounted for in the modelling process. Motivated by a data application of meteorological data from the Philippines, we develop a joint modeling methodology that not only flexibly accounts for differences in data quality, but also allows us to gauge the quality of the different data sources.

In particular, this work combines two primary meteorological data sources for the Philippines: observational data from a sparse network of weather synoptic stations, and simulated outcomes from a numerical weather prediction model called the Global Spectral Model (PHClimate_PAGASA, ), which provides broad spatial coverage but typically biased due to sensitivity to model initialization and parameterization. The observational data from the weather stations are likely to be less biased, but they provide limited spatial coverage since key areas in space are under-sampled, as is evident in Figure 1. It is therefore potentially advantageous to simultaneously use both data sources through data fusion. Unlike approaches discussed in the literature so far, which are discussed in Section 1.2, this work accounts for calibration biases in the data fusion model, specifies a flexible bias formulation, defines a single and interpretable latent process for the different data sources, and specifies a measurement error for the monitoring stations data. A simulation study compares our proposed data fusion approach to the stations-only model. In the data application, we compare the predictions derived from the proposed data fusion approach, a model based on the data from the stations only, and another approach for data fusion called regression calibration using leave-group-out cross-validation (liu2022leave, ; adin2023automatic, ). Although the data application of the proposed data fusion model in this work only considers two data sources, the model and the framework extend to more than two data sources and are relevant beyond this specific scenario.

1.1 Meteorological data from the Philippines

The Philippines is an archipelagic country, covering an area of ca.Â 300 thousand km2 (see Figure 1), situated in tropical Southeast Asia. The eastern part and some southern parts of the country are mostly classified as tropical rainforest and is characterized by no distinct wet or dry season and a relatively high rainfall all year round (hess2011mcknight, ). On the other hand, most of the countryâ€™s western section is classified as tropical monsoon or tropical Savannah and is characterized by pronounced dry and wet seasons (beck2018present, ). Such spatio-temporal interaction is the basis for the climate types of the Philippines (PHClimate_PAGASA, ).

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) maintains a network of 56 weather synoptic stations which regularly record several meteorological variables such as temperature, relative humidity, and precipitation. The spatial locations of the weather stations are shown in Figure 1. It is a sparse network relative to the total surface area of the country. Some regions, especially in the northern part, are heavily undersampled. Reconstructing meteorological variable surfaces based only on the weather stations would therefore result in high uncertainty. To augment this sparsity problem in the stations data, PAGASA utilizes the outcomes of the Global Spectrum Model (GSM), which is a numerical weather prediction model maintained by the Japanese Meteorological Agency. The GSM provides forecast outputs of up to 132 hours four times a day (with initial times 0000, 0600, 1200, and 1800 UTC) within 4 hours of the initial time, and up to 264 hours twice a day (with initial time 0000 and 1200 UTC) within 7 hours of the initial time. As an example, Figure 1 shows the map of mean temperatures from the GSM for August 2019 at a spatial resolution of 0.5 degree, which corresponds to approximately 55km Ã—\timesÃ— 55 km. Although the figure shows the outcomes are gridded, these outcomes are interpreted by PAGASA as point-referenced at the centroids PHClimate_PAGASA .

The GSM outcomes have a much larger spatial coverage, but it is known that outputs from numerical weather models are biased (lawson2016handbook, ; bauer2015quiet, ). To assess this, we initially do spatial interpolation using the GSM values on three meteorological variables of interest â€“ temperature, relative humidity, and log-transformed rainfall amounts â€“ and then predict the values at the locations of the weather stations. This is done by fitting the following geostatistical model:

We fit this model using INLA and the SPDE method rue2009approximate ; lindgren2011explicit . We then predict the values of wâ¢(ğ’”,t)ğ‘¤ğ’”ğ‘¡w(\bm{s},t)italic_w ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ) at the locations of the weather stations and then compare the predicted and the observed values. The resulting scatter plots in Figure 2 show a general agreement of the two sets of values, but a clear bias is visible. Figure 2 highlights specific weather stations and it is apparent, especially for temperature, that there is a spatially-varying additive bias and a constant multiplicative bias parameter since the GSM outcomes from a specific weather station seem parallel to the regression line. For the other two meteorological variables, it is also clear that there is a spatially varying additive bias, but accounting for spatially-varying or time-varying multiplicative bias might also be necessary.

Figure 2 also shows that the quality of the GSM outcomes for the three variables varies. The discrepancy in the outcomes between the GSM and weather stations for the rainfall data is bigger than for the other two meteorological variables. The proposed data fusion model, which is discussed in Section 2, is able to gauge the relative quality of the GSM outcomes for the three meteorological variables.

PAGASA provided the aggregated data at the monthly level in terms of the mean temperature, mean relative humidity, and the total precipitation from January 2019 to December 2020. In particular, the GSM outcomes are simulated from an initial time of 0000 UTC. The reason for using monthly temporal scale is that we will use the model predictions as an input to an epidemiological model, particularly with the Dengue fever cases as the response variable, which are usually available as counts at the monthly level (naish2014climate, ; abdullah2022association, ). The specific goal in this work, therefore, is to reconstruct monthly surfaces of meteorological variables, particularly temperature, relative humidity, and precipitation.

1.2 Current data fusion approaches

One statistical model for data fusion called Bayesian melding was proposed by fuentes2005model and discussed in lawson2016handbook . The primary motivation in their work is in modelling the concentration of air pollutants and its public health implication. The Bayesian melding model is based on the assumption that all data sources are error-prone realizations of a common latent spatial process. forlani2020joint proposed another data fusion model, but instead of assuming a common single latent process for the observed outcomes, they assumed several latent processes which are shared across all the observation data. But these different latent processes do not have a clear interpretation; in fact, these processes were simply referred to as spatial random effects. This approach is also closely related to the so-called coregionalization model (schmidt2003bayesian, ). The original melding model in Equations (1) to (3) assumes a single common latent process and has a clear interpretation as the true process and that the different observation data are error-prone realizations of the process with varying levels and degree of measurement error. The model in Equations (7) to (9) deviates from this general principle.

One bottleneck with the melding model in Equations (1) to (3) is that it requires considerable computational effort because of the change-of-support integral in Equation (4). A model which tries to overcome this difficulty was proposed in (sahu2010fusing, ), given by:

A limitation of this model is that it considers the underlying true process as discrete and that it can only provide gridded predictions of the true process.

Another statistical approach for doing data fusion, called the regression calibration approach, fits a regression model using the outcomes of the numerical prediction model as a predictor and the observational data as the response variable. The model is given by

(13)

Here, Î±0â¢(ğ’”)subscriptğ›¼0ğ’”\alpha_{0}(\bm{s})italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) and Î±1â¢(ğ’”)subscriptğ›¼1ğ’”\alpha_{1}(\bm{s})italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) are spatially varying additive and multiplicative biases, while w2â¢(Bğ’”)subscriptğ‘¤2subscriptğµğ’”w_{2}(B_{\bm{s}})italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is the value of the numerical forecast model at the grid BğµBitalic_B which contains the point location ğ’”ğ’”\bm{s}bold_italic_s. chen2021novel used this approach to estimate chlorophyll-A concentration over eutrophic lakes, lee2017rigorous to model air quality, and in berrocal2010spatio to model ozone concentration. Obviously, there is a computational advantage with this approach since it only uses the values of w2â¢(B)subscriptğ‘¤2ğµw_{2}(B)italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_B ) linked to a stations data w1â¢(ğ’”)subscriptğ‘¤1ğ’”w_{1}(\bm{s})italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) to fit the model, and then uses the full data w2â¢(B)subscriptğ‘¤2ğµw_{2}(B)italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_B ) for predictions. A limitation of the calibration framework is that it assumes that the observed measurements w1â¢(ğ’”)subscriptğ‘¤1ğ’”w_{1}(\bm{s})italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) are the gold standard, even though it is very likely to have instrumental errors (lawson2016handbook, ). Also, since w2â¢(B)subscriptğ‘¤2ğµw_{2}(B)italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_B ) is used as a predictor, then it cannot contain missing values. However, remote-sensed data can be missing due to cloud cover and highly reflective surfaces (lawson2016handbook, ). In addition, the resolution of the predicted latent surface for the quantity of interest depends on the resolution of w2â¢(B)subscriptğ‘¤2ğµw_{2}(B)italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_B ). (forlani2020joint, ) performed a comparison of the melding model and the regression calibration approach in a specific data application. The results show that the Bayesian melding model gave better model predictions compared to the regression calibration approach.

Unlike the approaches discussed so far, this work accounts for calibration biases in the data fusion model, specifies a flexible bias formulation, defines a single and interpretable latent processes for the different data sources, and specifies a measurement error for the stations data. In particular, we specify a random field for the additive bias Î±0â¢(ğ’”)subscriptğ›¼0ğ’”\alpha_{0}(\bm{s})italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) which we call an error field. Furthermore, we use a flexible specification by assuming that the error field is a time-varying random field and that Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is constant in space and time. Finally, our proposed model treats the outcomes of numerical prediction models as point-referenced at the centroids of the grids BğµBitalic_B, which is the same strategy as in (forlani2020joint, ; villejo2023data, ; lee2017rigorous, ). A comparison between the predictions from using the proposed data fusion model, the stations-only model, and the regression calibration approach in the real data application was done using the leave-group-out crossvalidation. We also conducted a simulation study in order to assess the benefits of doing data fusion under specific scenarios.

Monte Carlo methods have been the standard approach to doing inference with Bayesian melding model (falk2010estimating, ; vsevvcikova2011uncertain, ; liu2011empirical, ; poole2000inference, ). In recent years, the use of the integrated nested Laplace approximation (INLA) paired with the stochastic partial differential equations (SPDE) approach has been widely used (rue2009approximate, ; lindgren2011explicit, ). The INLA method is a deterministic approach for doing Bayesian inference for latent Gaussian models. Moreover, the SPDE method is another efficient computational method to estimate Gaussian fields of the MatÃ©rn type (lindgren2011explicit, ). One challenge in the proposed model, which is discussed in more detail in Section 2.2, is that it involves non-linear components primarily due to the Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT multiplicative bias parameter as shown in Equation 3. To overcome this issue, we primarily use Bayesian model averaging with INLA for model inference.

Section 2 discusses the framework and the data fusion model, while section 3 discusses the model estimation approaches. Sections 4 and 5 discusses the results from a simulation study and the application to real data, respectively.

2.2 Proposed Model

Using Equations (14) and (15) to represent the two data sources, we propose the following data fusion model for the meteorological data:

3 Model Estimation

The estimation approach uses the integrated nested Laplace approximation (INLA) which is a method for doing deterministic Bayesian inference for hierarchical models which are latent Gaussian (rue2009approximate, ). The joint model in Equations (16) to (18) is a latent Gaussian model which becomes obvious after rewriting it, in vector form, as

The fixed effects ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta}bold_italic_Î² are given a non-informative prior which is Gaussian with mean zero and a large variance, while the random fields ğƒtsubscriptğƒğ‘¡\bm{\xi}_{t}bold_italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğœ¶0tsubscriptğœ¶subscript0ğ‘¡{\bm{\alpha}}_{0_{t}}bold_italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT follow a Gaussian autoregressive structure as described in Equations (19) to (22). The hyperparameters include the parameters of the MatÃ©rn field ğ1â¢tsubscriptğ1ğ‘¡\bm{\omega}_{1t}bold_italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, particularly Ïƒ1,Ï1,subscriptğœ1subscriptğœŒ1\sigma_{1},\rho_{1},italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , and Ï•1subscriptitalic-Ï•1\phi_{1}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the parameters of the error field field, namely Ïƒ2,Ï2subscriptğœ2subscriptğœŒ2\sigma_{2},\rho_{2}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Ï•2subscriptitalic-Ï•2\phi_{2}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The measurement error variance parameters Ïƒe12subscriptsuperscriptğœ2subscriptğ‘’1\sigma^{2}_{e_{1}}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ïƒe22subscriptsuperscriptğœ2subscriptğ‘’2\sigma^{2}_{e_{2}}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are also considered hyperparameters. The aforementioned hyperparameters are given penalized complexity (PC) priors fuglstad2019constructing ; simpson2017penalising . PC priors are weakly informative priors which penalize the complexity of Gaussian random fields by shrinking the range towards infinity and the marginal variance towards zero fuglstad2019constructing . These are defined and expressed through probability statements of the type â„™â¢(Ïƒ>Ïƒo)=Î½1â„™ğœsubscriptğœosubscriptğœˆ1\mathbb{P}(\sigma>\sigma_{\text{o}})=\nu_{1}blackboard_P ( italic_Ïƒ > italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and â„™â¢(Ï<Ïo)=Î½2â„™ğœŒsubscriptğœŒosubscriptğœˆ2\mathbb{P}(\rho<\rho_{\text{o}})=\nu_{2}blackboard_P ( italic_Ï < italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Î½1,Î½2âˆˆ(0,1)subscriptğœˆ1subscriptğœˆ201\nu_{1},\nu_{2}\in(0,1)italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) are probability values chosen by the user, while Ïƒosubscriptğœo\sigma_{\text{o}}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ÏosubscriptğœŒo\rho_{\text{o}}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are also user-defined values of the parameters. The variance parameters Ïƒe12subscriptsuperscriptğœ2subscriptğ‘’1\sigma^{2}_{e_{1}}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ïƒe22subscriptsuperscriptğœ2subscriptğ‘’2\sigma^{2}_{e_{2}}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are also given PC priors.

A potential issue is that Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a scaling parameter of an unknown Gaussian field, ğ’tâ¢ğœ·+ğƒtsubscriptğ’ğ‘¡ğœ·subscriptğƒğ‘¡\bm{Z}_{t}\bm{\beta}+\bm{\xi}_{t}bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î² + bold_italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Although this violates the latent Gaussian assumption of INLA, this model specification could still be estimated in the INLA framework by doing data augmentation, which in consequence considers Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as a model hyperparameter (muff2015bayesian, ; martins2013bayesian, ; ruiz2012direct, ; villejo2023data, ). However, scaling parameters are typically difficult to estimate and the model could run into numerical issues in such a scenario. Hence, we explore in this work the use of a Bayesian model averaging (BMA) approach with INLA (gomez2020bayesian, ). This approach allows us to fit the data fusion model conditional on Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. When Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is fixed, the proposed data fusion model in Equations (23) to (26) is latent Gaussian.

Fitting the data fusion model conditional on Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a viable approach since we have a sensible set of values for Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which is on a grid centered at 1. When Î±1=1subscriptğ›¼11\alpha_{1}=1italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, this implies that there is no multiplicative bias in ğ’˜2â¢tsubscriptğ’˜2ğ‘¡\bm{w}_{2t}bold_italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; and the further the value of Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is away from 1, the more serious the multiplicative bias in ğ’˜2â¢tsubscriptğ’˜2ğ‘¡\bm{w}_{2t}bold_italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

All other posterior quantities of interest and all predictions are computed using model averaging. A disadvantage of the model averaging approach is that it requires us to fit the models conditional on each Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT value which can be inefficient especially for large spatio-temporal datasets.

Moreover, we use the stochastic partial differential equations (SPDE) approach to fit the MatÃ©rn fields in the model, particularly, ğ1â¢tsubscriptğ1ğ‘¡\bm{\omega}_{1t}bold_italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ2â¢tsubscriptğ2ğ‘¡\bm{\omega}_{2t}bold_italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The SPDE method approximates a Gaussian field with MatÃ©rn covariance function using a Gaussian Markov random field which has a sparse precision matrix and therefore allows fast model inference (lindgren2011explicit, ).

4 Simulation Study

In this section, we perform a simulation study with the aim to show that data fusion allows us to recover more accurate predictions of the latent process of interest and better estimates of model parameters. To simulate our data, we use the shapefile of the Belo horizonte region in Brazil, available in the R package spdep (bivand2015comparing, ). This region has a total surface area of ca 330 km2superscriptkm2\text{km}^{2}km start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We perform the simulation study on a purely spatial context and simulate the process of interest as:

To illustrate the difference in the severity of the biases between wâ¢(ğ’”i)ğ‘¤subscriptğ’”ğ‘–w(\bm{s}_{i})italic_w ( bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and wâ¢(ğ’ˆj)ğ‘¤subscriptğ’ˆğ‘—w(\bm{g}_{j})italic_w ( bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), we generate a specific data example from Equations (33) and (34), with nM=10subscriptğ‘›ğ‘€10n_{M}=10italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 10 stations and with the ğ’˜2subscriptğ’˜2\bm{w}_{2}bold_italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT centroids shown in Figure 3c. The point locations of the 10 stations are shown in Figure 5a. Figure 4 shows a comparison of the biases between the outcomes of w1â¢(ğ’”i)subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ’”ğ‘–w_{1}(\bm{s}_{i})italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and w2â¢(ğ’ˆj)subscriptğ‘¤2subscriptğ’ˆğ‘—w_{2}(\bm{g}_{j})italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). The observed data at the 10 stations closely corresponds to the truth as shown in Figure 4a. On the other hand, the outcomes of w2â¢(ğ’ˆj)subscriptğ‘¤2subscriptğ’ˆğ‘—w_{2}(\bm{g}_{j})italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) are more biased and also overestimates the truth because of the multiplicative bias parameter Î±1>1subscriptğ›¼11\alpha_{1}>1italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 1 as shown in Figure 4b. Figure 4c shows that there is a big discrepancy between the outcomes at the stations and the outcomes from the numerical prediction model at the locations of the stations. This plot is similar to Figure 2 which shows the discrepancies in the values between the two data sources for the real data application.

Our main interest here is to understand if jointly modeling the two data sources offers advantages and how these change with the density or sparsity of the weather stations. We therefore consider three different cases. The first scenario consists of only nM=10subscriptğ‘›ğ‘€10n_{M}=10italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 10 stations and with severe undersampling (Figure 5a). In the second case, we have nM=25subscriptğ‘›ğ‘€25n_{M}=25italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 25 stations, and a large area that is undersampled (Figure 5b). The third case has nM=40subscriptğ‘›ğ‘€40n_{M}=40italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 40 stations which are more uniformly distributed over the study area (Figure 5c). The location of the stations are held constant for all the data replicates so that the configuration of the spatial locations does not influence the results.

4.1 Model definition and estimation

We compare two approaches for estimating the latent process of interest. The first approach uses only the data from the stations and fits the following model:

Note that the matching priors are not necessarily more informative than the non-matching priors and that both cases are a weakly informative specification of the priors.

We use the inlabru library to fit the models. The first approach which only uses the data from the stations is straightforward to fit. For the data fusion model, we use the Bayesian model averaging approach with INLA as discussed in Section 3. We define a regular grid of Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values centered on 1. Defining the grid around 1 is reasonable since Î±1=1subscriptğ›¼11\alpha_{1}=1italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 implies that there is no multiplicative bias in the numerical forecast model. The weights of the different models for model averaging are computed using Equation (30). We use a uniform prior for Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in computing the weights.

We use the fitted models to estimate the values of the true process xâ¢(ğ’”)ğ‘¥ğ’”x(\bm{s})italic_x ( bold_italic_s ) over a set of locations ğ’”ğ’”\bm{s}bold_italic_s which defines a prediction grid in the study domain ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S. Here the vector ğ˜ğ˜\mathbf{Y}bold_Y indicates the observed data used to fit the model, so either ğ˜=ğ’˜1ğ˜subscriptğ’˜1\mathbf{Y}=\bm{w}_{1}bold_Y = bold_italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or ğ˜={ğ’˜1,ğ’˜2}ğ˜subscriptğ’˜1subscriptğ’˜2\mathbf{Y}=\{\bm{w}_{1},\bm{w}_{2}\}bold_Y = { bold_italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } for the stations-only model and the data fusion model, respectively.

The DS score for a prediction on yğ‘¦yitalic_y is given by

    (yâˆ’ğ”¼â„±â¢(y))2ğ•â„±â¢(y)+logâ¡[ğ•â„±â¢(y)],superscriptğ‘¦subscriptğ”¼â„±ğ‘¦2subscriptğ•â„±ğ‘¦subscriptğ•â„±ğ‘¦\dfrac{\Big{(}y-\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{F}}(y)\Big{)}^{2}}{\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{F% }}(y)}+\log[\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{F}}(y)],divide start_ARG ( italic_y - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_y ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_y ) end_ARG + roman_log [ blackboard_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_y ) ] , (35)

where ğ”¼â„±â¢(y)subscriptğ”¼â„±ğ‘¦\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{F}}(y)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_y ) and ğ•â„±â¢(y)subscriptğ•â„±ğ‘¦\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{F}}(y)blackboard_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_y ) is the mean and variance of the predictive distribution â„±â¢(y)â„±ğ‘¦\mathcal{F}(y)caligraphic_F ( italic_y ).

The first metric is a measure of the average discrepancy between the estimated field and the true values of the latent field, ğ’™â¢(ğ’”)ğ’™ğ’”\bm{x}(\bm{s})bold_italic_x ( bold_italic_s ), while the second metric assesses the average uncertainty in the estimated field. We approximate both integrals above using the estimated values on the prediction grid. The third metric is another proper scoring rule which depends on the predictive mean and variance of the observed data (gneiting2007strictly, ). We are particularly interested in the predictions for the observational data ğ’˜1subscriptğ’˜1\bm{w}_{1}bold_italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Similar to the first two metrics, a lower value for the average DS score is preferred. We also look at the accuracy of the parameter estimates by computing the relative error and the posterior uncertainty. All simulation results are computed based on 600 independent data replicates.

4.3 Simulation study results

Figures 6 and 7 show a comparison of the squared-errors and the posterior uncertainty in an estimated field, respectively, between the stations-only model and the data fusion model on the data example in Figure 3 and 4. The spatial location of the stations are shown as white points in Figures 6 and 7. The squared errors from the stations-only model, shown in Figure 6, are generally much larger than the squared errors from the data fusion model. The posterior uncertainty of the latent field is also much larger for the stations-only model as shown in Figure 7. Also, as expected, the posterior uncertainty at the location of the stations is lower than elsewhere, which is very apparent for the stations-only model. The average squared error for the stations-only model and data fusion model for this specific case is 0.53 and 0.27, respectively, while the average posterior uncertainty is 0.80 and 0.48, respectively. The average DS scores are 1.02 and -0.65, respectively.

Figure 8a shows a plot of the average squared errors of the estimated latent field over ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S based on the 600 data replicates for the different simulation scenarios. The data fusion approach clearly gives smaller average squared errors, especially when the data on the stations is very sparse. The same plot also shows a comparison of the average squared errors between the use of matching and non-matching priors. The results show that there is no substantial difference with respect to the priors. Figure 8b shows the results for the average posterior uncertainty. It shows that the data fusion approach also gives lower uncertainty estimates and that higher number of stations is associated with smaller uncertainty. In addition, the same figure shows that there is no difference in the average posterior uncertainty between the use of matching and non-matching priors. Finally, Figure 8c shows the average DS scores. The average DS scores are also smaller with the data fusion approach. Furthermore, it also shows that the average DS scores tend to decrease with the number of stations, and that the use of either matching or non-matching priors gives roughly the same values on the average.

Figure 9 shows a comparison of the average relative error and average posterior uncertainty for two model hyperparameters: the marginal standard deviation of the spatial field Î¾â¢(ğ’”)ğœ‰ğ’”\xi(\bm{s})italic_Î¾ ( bold_italic_s ) (in Figure 9a), and the standard deviation of the measurement error in the stations e1â¢(ğ’”)subscriptğ‘’1ğ’”e_{1}(\bm{s})italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s ) (in Figure 9b). There is a clear benefit from doing data fusion for all scenarios, especially when the data from the stations is very sparse. The average relative errors are generally smaller when matching priors are used. The average relative error tends to decrease with more stations, especially for the stations-only model. Figures 19 and 20 in Appendix section 10.1 shows the results for the fixed effects, Î²0subscriptğ›½0\beta_{0}italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Î²1subscriptğ›½1\beta_{1}italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the the range parameter of the spatial field Î¾â¢(ğ’”)ğœ‰ğ’”\xi(\bm{s})italic_Î¾ ( bold_italic_s ), respectively. The results show that the average relative error and average posterior uncertainty are also smaller for the data fusion approach. Also, the errors and the uncertainty in the estimates from the stations-only model is higher when the number of stations is very sparse. For ÏÎ¾subscriptğœŒğœ‰\rho_{\xi}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¾ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the use of matching priors seem to give higher relative errors compared to the use of non-matching priors.

Finally, Figure 21 in Appendix section 10.1 shows a summary of the model averaging weights of the INLA models for each Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT value. The weight for Î±1=1.1subscriptğ›¼11.1\alpha_{1}=1.1italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1.1 is the highest for all the scenarios. Moreover, the weights decrease as the value of Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT goes further away from 1.1. The use of either matching or non-matching PC priors does not seem to substantially affect the weights.

5 Results for Meteorological Data from the Philippines

This section presents in detail the results of the proposed data fusion model applied to meteorological data in the Philippines. Section 5.1, 5.2, 5.3 discuss the results for temperature, relative humidity, and rainfall, respectively, while section 5.4 presents the results of the leave-group-out cross-validation.

5.1 Temperature

In modelling temperature, we have the following form for the fixed effects in the latent process:

Temperatureâ¢(ğ’”,t)=Î²0+Î²1â¢logâ¡(Elevationâ¢(ğ’”,t))+Î²2â¢Cool+Î²3â¢ClimateTypeTemperatureğ’”ğ‘¡subscriptğ›½0subscriptğ›½1Elevationğ’”ğ‘¡subscriptğ›½2Coolsubscriptğ›½3ClimateType\text{Temperature}(\bm{s},t)=\beta_{0}+\beta_{1}\log\Big{(}\text{Elevation}(% \bm{s},t)\Big{)}+\beta_{2}\text{Cool}+\beta_{3}\text{ClimateType}Temperature ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ) = italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( Elevation ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ) ) + italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Cool + italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ClimateType (36)

There are two prevailing seasons in the Philippines: rainy or dry season (PHClimate_PAGASA, ). Rainy season lasts from June to November, while the rest of the year is generally considered dry. The rainy season is also considered a hot episode in the country. On the other hand, the dry season is further categorized into either a cool dry or a hot dry period, where the former lasts from December to February and the latter from March to May. Hence, we define the â€˜Coolâ€™ variable in Equation (36) as a binary variable which takes a value of â€˜1â€™ for months December to February and a value of â€˜0â€™ for the other months. The climate type variable is also a binary variable which takes â€˜1â€™ for the eastern section of the country and â€˜0â€™ for the western section. The eastern part of the country is characterized as having no distinct wet or dry season and with relatively high rainfall all year round. On the other hand, most of the western section of the country are characterized as having pronounced dry and wet seasons (beck2018present, ).

Penalised complexity (PC) priors are used for the MatÃ©rn field parameters fuglstad2019constructing ; simpson2017penalising . The parameter values for the MatÃ©rn PC priors are as follows: Ï1â¢o=Ï2â¢o=300â¢km,Ïƒ1â¢o=0.07,Ïƒ2â¢o=0.01formulae-sequencesubscriptğœŒ1osubscriptğœŒ2o300kmformulae-sequencesubscriptğœ1o0.07subscriptğœ2o0.01\rho_{1\text{o}}=\rho_{2\text{o}}=300\;\text{km},\sigma_{1\text{o}}=0.07,% \sigma_{2\text{o}}=0.01italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 300 km , italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.07 , italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.01. The value for the range parameters is one-third the maximum distance of the spatial domain. The value for Ïƒ1â¢osubscriptğœ1o\sigma_{1\text{o}}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the standard deviation of the temperature values, while the value of Ïƒ2â¢osubscriptğœ2o\sigma_{2\text{o}}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is chosen to be some value smaller than Ïƒ1â¢osubscriptğœ1o\sigma_{1\text{o}}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT based on preliminary model results. The variance parameters of e1â¢(ğ’”i,t)subscriptğ‘’1subscriptğ’”ğ‘–ğ‘¡e_{1}(\bm{s}_{i},t)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) and e2â¢(ğ’ˆj,t)subscriptğ‘’2subscriptğ’ˆğ‘—ğ‘¡e_{2}(\bm{g}_{j},t)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) are also given PC priors, with Ïƒe1o=0.2subscriptğœsubscriptsubscriptğ‘’1o0.2\sigma_{{e_{1}}_{\text{o}}}=0.2italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.2 and Ïƒe2o=0.01subscriptğœsubscriptsubscriptğ‘’2o0.01\sigma_{{e_{2}}_{\text{o}}}=0.01italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.01. The probability value of all PC priors is set to be equal to 0.50. The rest of the model parameters are given the default non-informative priors.

We define a grid of values from 0.5 to 1.5 with a length step of 0.1 for the multiplicative bias parameter, Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A uniform prior was used for Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. An ensemble of INLA models were fitted for a fixed Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the BMA weights are computed using Equation 30. The marginal log-likelihoods logâ¡Ï€â¢(ğ˜|Î±1(k))ğœ‹conditionalğ˜superscriptsubscriptğ›¼1ğ‘˜\log\pi(\mathbf{Y}|\alpha_{1}^{(k)})roman_log italic_Ï€ ( bold_Y | italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and the corresponding BMA weights wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are shown in Appendix 10.2 Table 4. The results show that the weight of the model with Î±1=1subscriptğ›¼11\alpha_{1}=1italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 is approximately equal to 1, while the rest of the models do not have a significant contribution in the model averaging.

Shown in Table 1 are the posterior estimates of the fixed effects for the stations-only model and the proposed data fusion model. The estimated fixed effects for both models are quite similar, except for the climate type variable which is significant in the stations-only model but not in the proposed data fusion model. The uncertainty in the estimates for Î²1,Î²2subscriptğ›½1subscriptğ›½2\beta_{1},\beta_{2}italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Î²3subscriptğ›½3\beta_{3}italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are smaller for the data fusion model as expected. Elevation is negatively associated with temperature, i.e., it is colder at higher elevation. The â€˜Coolâ€™ binary variable is negatively associated with temperature, i.e., colder months (December, January, and February) have lower mean temperature compared to the rest of the months. The climate type variable is positively associated with temperature, which means that areas which are located in the eastern section of the country are warmer on the average than areas in the western section of the country.

The posterior estimates of the hyperparameters from the stations-only model and the proposed data fusion model are also quite similar (see Table 5 in Appendix section 10.2). In the data fusion model, the range parameter Ï1subscriptğœŒ1\rho_{1}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the spatial field is higher than the range parameter Ï2subscriptğœŒ2\rho_{2}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the error field. This means that the spatial field Î¾â¢(ğ’”,t)ğœ‰ğ’”ğ‘¡\xi(\bm{s},t)italic_Î¾ ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ) is smoother than the error field Î±0â¢(ğ’ˆ,t)subscriptğ›¼0ğ’ˆğ‘¡\alpha_{0}(\bm{g},t)italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_g , italic_t ). The spatial correlation in the temperature spatial field and the error field becomes negligible at a distance of around 765 km and 113 km, respectively. Also, the marginal standard deviation Ïƒ1subscriptğœ1\sigma_{1}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the spatial field is much larger than that of the error field Ïƒ2subscriptğœ2\sigma_{2}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The autocorrelation parameters Ï•1subscriptitalic-Ï•1\phi_{1}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ï•2subscriptitalic-Ï•2\phi_{2}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in both the spatial field and error field are close to 1 which suggests a high degree of dependence in time.

Figure 10a shows a comparison of the estimated temperature fields for August 2019 between the stations-only model and the proposed data fusion model. The estimated fields look very similar, although the estimated field from the data fusion model is smoother. The dark spot in the northern part of the country is primarily mountainous which makes it cooler than the other parts of the country. Figure 10b shows the corresponding uncertainty estimates or standard deviation (SD) in the predicted fields. As expected, the standard deviations are smaller at the locations of the weather stations (in green points) which is more apparent for the stations-only model. Also, there is more uncertainty in the predictions from the stations-only model especially in the islands in the lower left portion. The average of the posterior standard deviation of the estimated fields from using the stations-only model and data fusion model is 1.2388 and 0.7711, respectively. Figures 22 in Appendix section 10.2 shows the estimated spatial fields, Î¾â¢(ğ’”,t)ğœ‰ğ’”ğ‘¡\xi(\bm{s},t)italic_Î¾ ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ), for the stations-only model and data fusion model for the same month. The spatial structure looks quite similar as the estimated temperature fields in Figures 10a.

Figure 11 shows the estimated error field Î±^0â¢(ğ’ˆj,t)subscript^ğ›¼0subscriptğ’ˆğ‘—ğ‘¡\hat{\alpha}_{0}(\bm{g}_{j},t)over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) for the GSM data for the same month, August 2019. We can relate this plot with Figure 2 which shows the discrepancies in the values between the weather stations and the GSM outcomes. From Figure 11, the estimated error outcomes around the neighborhood of Baguio station (in blue) is the highest, i.e., the GSM has overestimated the temperature value in this area. This is consistent with Figure 2, which shows that the GSM outcomes are larger than the observed data at the station. Similarly, the estimated error values in the neighborhood of Malaybalay station (in red) is negative, and is consistent with Figure 2, which shows that there is a negative bias in the outcomes from the GSM in this area. For Tanay station (in cyan), the estimated error is around zero which is also expected since Figure 2 shows that there seems to be no additive bias in the GSM outcomes.

We also explored the regression calibration approach for doing data fusion which uses the GSM outcomes as a predictor in the model, as explained in Equation (13). The model estimates are shown in Appendix 10.2 Table 6. The corresponding predicted temperature field for August 2019, the posterior uncertainty, and the estimated spatial field for the same month are shown in Appendix 10.2 Figure 23. The results from the regression calibration approach are quite similar to the stations-only model. The proposed data fusion model has the smallest posterior uncertainty among the three approaches. A better comparison of the three approaches is discussed in section 5.4 which shows the cross-validation results.

This shows that the error field can be effectively used to calibrate the GSM outcomes for temperature.

5.2 Relative Humidity

In modelling relative humidity (RH), we have the following form for the fixed effects in the latent process:

logâ¡(RHâ¢(ğ’”,t))=Î²0+Î²1â¢logâ¡Tempâ¢(ğ’”,t)+Î²2â¢(logâ¡Tempâ¢(ğ’”,t))2+Î²3â¢logâ¡(Elevationâ¢(ğ’”,t))+Î²4â¢ClimateTypeRHğ’”ğ‘¡subscriptğ›½0subscriptğ›½1Tempğ’”ğ‘¡subscriptğ›½2superscriptTempğ’”ğ‘¡2subscriptğ›½3Elevationğ’”ğ‘¡subscriptğ›½4ClimateType\log\Big{(}\text{RH}(\bm{s},t)\Big{)}=\beta_{0}+\beta_{1}\log\text{Temp}(\bm{s% },t)+\beta_{2}\Big{(}\log\text{Temp}(\bm{s},t)\Big{)}^{2}+\beta_{3}\log\Big{(}% \text{Elevation}(\bm{s},t)\Big{)}+\beta_{4}\text{ClimateType}roman_log ( RH ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ) ) = italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log Temp ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ) + italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_log Temp ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( Elevation ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ) ) + italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ClimateType (37)

Elevation and climate type are also used as predictors for the relative humidity model. In addition, we use log temperature and its quadratic term as a predictor in the model as recommended by (PHClimate_PAGASA, ). This non-linear relationship is also established in the atmospheric science literature (goody1995principles, ). A log transformation on temperature is possible in the data since the range of its values for the Philippines which is a tropical country is from 16âˆ˜C to 32âˆ˜C. This is also done in the literature, such as in sanders2007temperature . In particular, we use the predictions from the temperature model in Equation (36), in both the locations of the weather stations and the point locations of the GSM outcomes, as the input in the linear predictor in Equation (37).

PC priors are used for the MatÃ©rn field parameters. The values used to define the MatÃ©rn PC priors for the two range parameters are the same as the temperature model (Ï1â¢o=300,Ï2â¢o=50formulae-sequencesubscriptğœŒ1o300subscriptğœŒ2o50\rho_{1\text{o}}=300,\rho_{2\text{o}}=50italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 300 , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 50). For the marginal standard deviations of the fields, we have Ïƒ1â¢o=0.08subscriptğœ1o0.08\sigma_{1\text{o}}=0.08italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.08 and Ïƒ2â¢o=0.01subscriptğœ2o0.01\sigma_{2\text{o}}=0.01italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.01. The former is the standard deviation of the log-transformed relative humidity values, while the value of Ïƒ2â¢osubscriptğœ2o\sigma_{2\text{o}}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is chosen to be some value smaller than Ïƒ1â¢osubscriptğœ1o\sigma_{1\text{o}}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The variance parameters of e1â¢(ğ’”i,t)subscriptğ‘’1subscriptğ’”ğ‘–ğ‘¡e_{1}(\bm{s}_{i},t)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) and e2â¢(ğ’ˆj,t)subscriptğ‘’2subscriptğ’ˆğ‘—ğ‘¡e_{2}(\bm{g}_{j},t)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) are also given PC priors, with Ïƒe1o=0.01subscriptğœsubscriptsubscriptğ‘’1o0.01\sigma_{{e_{1}}_{\text{o}}}=0.01italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.01 and Ïƒe2o=0.004subscriptğœsubscriptsubscriptğ‘’2o0.004\sigma_{{e_{2}}_{\text{o}}}=0.004italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.004. The probability value in the PC priors are also set equal to 0.5. The rest of the model parameters are given the default non-informative priors.

From the model averaging results, the model with Î±1=1subscriptğ›¼11\alpha_{1}=1italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 also gave the highest marginal log-likelihood value and with a weight close to 1. The marginal log-likelihoods logâ¡Ï€â¢(ğ˜|Î±1(k))ğœ‹conditionalğ˜superscriptsubscriptğ›¼1ğ‘˜\log\pi(\mathbf{Y}|\alpha_{1}^{(k)})roman_log italic_Ï€ ( bold_Y | italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and the corresponding BMA weights wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are shown in Appendix 10.3 Table 7. Table 2 shows the estimates of the fixed effects for the stations-only model and the proposed data fusion model. The posterior means of the fixed effects from the two approaches are comparable, although the climate type variable is not significant in the stations-only model. The estimates of the hyperparameters are shown in Appendix 10.3 Table 8.

Table 2 shows that there is a significant non-linear relationship between temperature and relative humidity. There is a positive correlation between the two variables for lower temperature values, but a negative correlation for high temperature values. The elevation variable is negatively associated with relative humidity. Moreover, the climate type variable is positively related with relative humidity which means that the areas in the eastern section of the country have higher relative humidity on the average than the western section. Similar to the results of the temperature data fusion model, the estimate of the range parameter Ï1subscriptğœŒ1\rho_{1}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the spatial field in the latent process Î¾â¢(ğ’”,t)ğœ‰ğ’”ğ‘¡\xi(\bm{s},t)italic_Î¾ ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ) is larger than the range parameter Ï2subscriptğœŒ2\rho_{2}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the error field Î±0â¢(ğ’”,t)subscriptğ›¼0ğ’”ğ‘¡\alpha_{0}(\bm{s},t)italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ) (see Appendix 10.3 Table 8). The spatial correlation in the relative humidity values becomes negligible at a distance of around 589 km, while the spatial correlation in the error field decays to a negligible value at a distance of 117 km. Moreover, the spatial variance of the spatial field is larger than that of the error field. The estimates of the AR parameter are both close to 1, although the estimated value of the parameter for the spatial field is higher than that of the error field.

Figures 13a and 13b show the estimated relative humidity fields for two different months, August 2019 and January 2020, using the proposed data fusion model and the stations-only model, respectively. These two specific months were chosen since August is characterized as a rainy month while January is considered a dry month PHClimate_PAGASA . The spatial structure in the predicted fields between the proposed data fusion model and the stations-only model is similar, although it is apparent that there is more smoothing in the estimates from the stations-only model. Figures 13a and 13b show that in the eastern section of the country, the level of relative humidity is similar for the two months. In the western section, particularly in the northwestern section, relative humidity is very high during August, which is a rainy month, and is very low during January, which is a dry month.

Figure 14 shows the uncertainty estimates of the estimated relative humidity fields in Figure 13. As expected, there is more uncertainty in the predictions from the stations-only model. The average of the posterior standard deviation in the predicted fields from using the stations-only model and the proposed data fusion model is 0.0394 and 0.0220, respectively. Also, the uncertainty estimates are smaller at the location of the weather stations shown in green points.

Figures 24 and 25a in Appendix 10.3 show the estimated spatial field of the latent process, Î¾â¢(ğ’”,t)ğœ‰ğ’”ğ‘¡\xi(\bm{s},t)italic_Î¾ ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ), for the same two months using the stations-only model and the proposed data fusion model, respectively. The same spatial patterns observed in the estimated relative humidity field as shown in Figure 13 are also evident in the estimated spatial fields. The spatial effects for the eastern part of the country are fairly constant for the two different months, although there is a slight increase in the values for the northeastern parts during August which is a rainy month. On the other hand, the spatial effects for the western part are higher during August and lower during January. Figure 25b in Appendix 10.3 shows the estimated error fields for the GSM outcomes on relative humidity for the same two months.

A regression calibration modelling approach was also explored for relative humidity. The model estimates are shown in Appendix 10.3 Table 9. The estimated relative humidity fields for August 2019 and January 2020 are shown in Appendix 10.3 Figure 27. The same spatial structure observed from Figure 13 are also observed from the estimated fields using the regression calibration approach. The corresponding posterior uncertainty and the estimated spatial fields for the same two months are shown in Appendix 10.3 Figure 28. Similar to the results for temperature, the estimated relative humidity fields and the corresponding posterior uncertainty using the regression calibration approach are quite similar to the stations-only model. The proposed data fusion model gave the smallest posterior uncertainty among the three approaches. The results from the cross-validation, which is a better way of doing model comparison, are discussed in section 5.4.

The plot shows a very close correspondence between the two values. Similar to the temperature model, the scatter plot shows that the estimated error fields can be effectively used to calibrate the GSM outcomes.

5.3 Rainfall

In modelling rainfall, the fixed effects in the latent process are as follows:

The â€˜Seasonâ€™ variable is binary which takes a value of â€˜1â€™ for months June to November (characterized as a wet period), and a value of â€˜0â€™ for the rest of the months which is the dry season in the country. Just like the relative humidity model, the log temperature and its squared term are also predictors in the rainfall model as recommended by PHClimate_PAGASA . We also used the predictions from the temperature model in Equation (36) as the input in the linear predictor in Equation (38). An interaction effect between climate type and season was considered to capture the climate dynamics of the country, also as recommended by PHClimate_PAGASA .

Shown in Figure 15 is the estimated marginal posterior distribution of Î±1subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{1}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Ï€â¢(Î±1|ğ˜)ğœ‹conditionalsubscriptğ›¼1ğ˜\pi(\alpha_{1}|\mathbf{Y})italic_Ï€ ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_Y ). The posterior mean is 0.6733 while the 95% credible interval estimate is (0.5607, 0.8353). Unlike the previous two meteorological variables, the multiplicative bias parameter for the GSM outcomes for rainfall is significantly different from 1, which implies a more severe bias for rainfall outcomes. This is expected since Figure 2 shows a big discrepancy between the interpolated GSM outcomes at the locations of the weather stations and the observed values at the weather stations. This also agrees with the insights from the LGOCV results discussed in Section 5.4.

Table 3 shows the estimates of the fixed effects for the stations-only model and the proposed data fusion model. The results show that log temperature has a non-linear association with log rainfall amounts. The correlation is positive for small values of log temperature and is negative for large log temperature values. Moreover, there is a significant interaction between season and climate type. In particular, the results show that the western section of the country has a pronounced dry and wet season. On the other hand, the eastern section of the country has a less pronounced dry and wet season and with more or less evenly distributed rainfall the whole year. This can be confirmed in Figures 16a and 16b which shows the predicted log rainfall fields using the proposed data fusion model and stations-only model, respectively, for two months - August 2019 (rainy month) and January 2020 (dry month). This climatic pattern is consistent with theory (beck2018present, ). Also, these are the same seasonal dynamics observed for relative humidity. The uncertainty estimates of the fields are shown in Figure 29 in Appendix 10.4. The log rainfall fields from the two approaches look quite similar but the uncertainty in the predictions from the proposed data fusion model is substantially smaller as expected. The estimated spatial fields and error fields for the same two months using the proposed data fusion model are shown in Figures 31a and 31b in Appendix 10.4, respectively, while Figure 30 in Appendix 10.4 shows the estimated spatial fields Î¾â¢(ğ’”,t)ğœ‰ğ’”ğ‘¡\xi(\bm{s},t)italic_Î¾ ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ) for the stations-only model.

Table 10 in Appendix 10.4 shows the estimates of the hyperparameters for both the stations-only model and the proposed data fusion model. Similar to the previous meteorological variables, the estimated range Ï1subscriptğœŒ1\rho_{1}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the spatial field in the latent process is larger than the estimated range Ï2subscriptğœŒ2\rho_{2}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the error field. This is also true for the estimated marginal variances of the two fields. The estimated autocorrelation parameters of the two fields are very different, with the AR parameter for the error field being much larger.

A regression calibration modelling approach was also explored for rainfall. The model estimates are shown in Appendix 10.4 Table 11. The predicted log rainfall fields for August 2019 and January 2020 are shown in Appendix 10.4 Figure 33. The same spatial structure observed from Figures 16a and 16b are also observed from Figure 33. The estimated log rainfall fields and the corresponding posterior uncertainty using the regression calibration approach (see Figure 33 and 34 in Appendix 10.4) are similar to the stations-only model. Although the proposed data fusion model gave the smallest posterior uncertainty among the three approaches, a better comparison are shown in the LGOCV results which are discussed in section 5.4.

Figure 32a in Appendix 10.4 shows a scatter plot of the observed log rainfall outcomes and the predicted values at the weather stations, i.e., w1â¢(ğ’”,t)subscriptğ‘¤1ğ’”ğ‘¡w_{1}(\bm{s},t)italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ) versus x^â¢(ğ’”,t)^ğ‘¥ğ’”ğ‘¡\hat{x}(\bm{s},t)over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ( bold_italic_s , italic_t ).
